description: From Anglo-Norman nounage, corresponding to non- +‎ age.

entries.meaning: The state of being under legal age; minority, the fact of being a minor. [from 15th c.]
examples: And since this life our nonage is, / And we in wardship to Thine angels be, / Native in heaven's fair palaces / Where we shall be but denizen'd by Thee;

description: From Late Latin nonagium, from nōnus (“ninth”).

entries.meaning: (obsolete, rare) A payment formerly made to the parish clergy upon the death of a parishioner, consisting of a ninth of the movable goods.
